awd_titl_txt: Spatiotemporal Inhomogeneity of Tropical Waves and Their Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
Tropical waves, also referred to as equatorial waves, are a key component of the weather of the tropics, and are known to play important roles in monsoon variability, El Nino events, and the formation of hurricanes and typhoons. The basic characteristics of tropical waves, including their size, shape and frequency, can be derived by solving an idealized model of their fundamental dynamics.  The resulting solutions are expressed in terms of sinusoidal waves, with successive ridges and troughs repeating uniformly around the equator.  Analysis methods that assume such extended wave trains can detect equatorial waves, and these methods confirm that observed waves largely match theoretical predictions.  But observed waves typically span a limited region and it can be desirable to study them using methods which make no assumptions regarding their global nature or longitudinal extent.

In this project tropical waves are identified and studied using the Multi-dimensional Ensemble Empirical Mode Decomposition (MEEMD), a time series analysis method pioneered by the PI and others (see AGS-1139479).  MEEMD is used to identify variability at each longitude along the equator at frequencies roughly corresponding to frequencies for particular waves. Additional information about the expected latitudinal shape of the waves is used to separate wave types which have similar frequencies.  Once the waves are identified in the data their behavior is further analyzed using techniques to determine characteristics such as equivalent depth, a measure of the depth of wave motions that can be related to the generation of waves by condensational heating in clouds.  The MEEMD technique has some advantages for representing the interaction of waves of different frequencies, and the MEEMD technique has been used to develop holo-spectral analysis, a method for quantifying wave interactions and studying their energetics.  One application of holo-spectral analysis here is to examine the modulation of equatorial waves by the Madden-Julian Oscillation, a much larger form of tropical variability which fluctuates slowly over the course of a month or two.

The work has broader impacts due to the importance of equatorial waves for the weather and climate of the tropics, as noted above.  The MEEMD and holo-spectral analysis tools developed in the project will be made available to the research community to ensure the scientific broader impacts of the project.  These tools have applicability in a variety of research fields beyond tropical meteorology, for example in the study of brain wave anomalies in neural disorders.  In addition, the project would provide support and training for a graduate student and a postdoc, thereby promoting the next generation of scientists in this  research area.

por.por_cntn:
A wave is a propagating dynamic disturbance (change from equilibrium) of one or more quantities in a spatiotemporal domain. Wave propagation is one of the two most fundamental ways to move energy from one location to others.  The improvement in understanding waves and their propagation can help us to understand the fundamental aspects of numerous phenomena. In atmospheric and climate dynamics, waves, their propagation characteristics, and their changes in varying medium are the key to understanding the developments of weather systems, circulation patterns, energy redistribution over space.

To understand tropical waves, analyzing long-term weather data and developing new theoretical understandings were two interwoven means. The traditinal analysis of tropical waves are mostly based on Fourier analysis, i.e., breaking any complicated variable field, such as temperature and winds, in terms of the sums of many sinusoidal waves with constand frequencies and wave numbers. However, the global domain Fourier transform-based methods have many drawbacks, often leading to confusing results that are hardly physically reconciable, bringing difficulties to understand the physics and dynamics operating behind many tropical phenomena. On the other hand, the major theoretical understanding of tropical waves were made mostly in 1960s under many ideal assumptions of wave and medium characteristics, with some of those hardly applicable to real world. Therefore, new improvements in diagnosing and theorizing have been desired for a long time.

Our projected was designed to meet this chellenge. At the end of this project, we have achieved major progress in the following areas:

1. We built a novel local wave diagnose method and developed its corresponding computational software for community use. We made a comprehensive comparison between the wave characteristics revealed using traditional methods and our new spatiotemporally local approach, showing the significant advantages of our new wave diagnose method. Wave events extracted using our new method and package are highly physical without taking refining steps. This new analysis package has already assisted and will continue help us to systematically extract spatiotemporally inhomogeneous information of tropical waves and directly quantify their interactions. The improved quantification of spatiotemporal inhomogeneity of tropical waves will further help to assess the role of convective heating in exciting tropical waves, as well as to quantitatively characterize interaction between waves of different types and different spatiotemporal scales.

2. We made progress in theoretical understanding of tropical waves. By far, the theoretical treatments of waves in a medium often contains ideal assumptions that are hardly applicable to the waves in tropical atmosphere. Some pioneering works published in 1960s introduced spatiotemporally local wavenumber and frequency and found conservative quantities related to amplitude change through wave propagation in a varying mean flow. However, the applications of these theoretical developments to real world has been barred by the lack of diagnosing capability of identifying local wavenumber and frequency. By introducing moving coordinate system, we transform a problem of waves in an inhomogeneous moving media to a problem of waves in a static media and proposed a general principle for wave propagation in a varying mean flow: an observer moving with the varying mean flow should observe the same wave dispersion relationship (a function that related wavenumber, wave frequency, and medium environmental parameters) as that in a non-moving medium by a local observer. With this development, we are able to find the consistency between diagnosed waves and their theoretical characteristics. We further derived a new differential equation that governs the amplitude variation in space as wave propagates. This equation successfully explains the observes wave characteristics, especially its spatiotemporal locality. These developments, we believe, formed a major breakthrough in the study of waves. 

3. Another significant advance in this project is related to the understanding of the dynamics of convectively coupled equatorial waves and its self-aggregation. The essential part of this development is to reveal the physical factors previously unaware and not included in the previous theoretical formulation of the interaction between waves and convections. By understanding the major cause of the instability of a earlier theoretical model (called wave-CISK), we designed a new parameterization scheme that make wave-CISK non-instantaneous. When we integrated this new paramenterization scheme into the Weather Research and Forecasting model, which has been widely used in opertational forecasting and climate research, the simulation of Madden-Julian Oscillations have been dramtically improved. It is noted here that the simulation of Madden-Julian Oscillations has been a long-lasting challenge to the weather-climate research communities.

4. The newly improved wave theories concerns waves in general varying medium; and therefore, their applications are not limited to tropical waves. Rather, they can find applications in numerous scientific and engineering fields that use waves to understand the physics and dynamics behind many phenomena. In addition, the analysis methods developed are also applicable to numerous fields.
